text: The LORD God is my strength, and he will make my feet like hinds' feet, and he will make me to walk upon mine high places. To the chief singer on my stringed instruments.
text_kjv: The LORD God is my strength, and he will make my feet like hinds' feet, and he will make me to walk upon mine high places. To the chief singer on my stringed instruments.
text_niv: The Sovereign Lord is my strength;he makes my feet like the feet of a deer,he enables me to go on the heights.For the director of music. On my stringed instruments.
text_esv: GOD, the Lord, is my strength; he makes my feet like the deer's; he makes me tread on my high places.  To the choirmaster: with stringed  instruments.
text_nlt: The Sovereign LORD is my strength!He makes me as surefooted as a deer,able to tread upon the heights. (For the choir director: This prayer is to be accompanied by stringed instruments.)
text_msg: Counting on God's Rule to prevail,I take heart and gain strength.I run like a deer.I feel like I'm king of the mountain!(For congregational use, with a full orchestra.)
text_nasb: The Lord GOD is my strength, And He has made my feet like hinds' [feet], And makes me walk on my high places. For the choir director, on my stringed instruments.
context: Habakkuk was a prophet who lived during a tumultuous period in Judah's history, likely the late 7th century BC, around the time of the rise of the Babylonian empire. The book itself is structured as a dialogue between Habakkuk and God, concerning the problem of evil and injustice. Habakkuk witnesses the increasing wickedness within Judah and questions God's apparent inaction. God initially responds by revealing his plan to use the Babylonians as an instrument of judgment against Judah, a response that further troubles Habakkuk, as the Babylonians were even more wicked than Judah. The entire book revolves around this tension, with Habakkuk grappling with God's justice and sovereignty in the face of suffering. Chapter 3, from which this verse comes, is a prayer or psalm of Habakkuk, expressing his faith and trust in God despite the impending doom. It is written in a poetic and liturgical style, reminiscent of the Psalms, and possibly intended for public worship. The phrase 'To the chief singer on my stringed instruments' suggests that the prayer was meant to be set to music and used in temple services. Understanding the historical context of national crisis, moral decay, and Habakkuk's personal struggle with faith provides a crucial backdrop to appreciate the profound declaration of trust and hope found in this final verse. The 'high places' mentioned were often associated with pagan worship, though in this context, they likely represent positions of safety, security, and spiritual victory.
meaning: Theologically, Habakkuk 3:19 embodies several key truths about God and His relationship with believers. First, it proclaims that 'The LORD God is my strength.' This is not a general acknowledgment of a higher power but a personal declaration of reliance on Yahweh as the source of all power and resilience. It signifies that Habakkuk's ability to endure hardship and maintain faith stems directly from God's enabling presence. Second, the verse speaks of God making 'my feet like hinds' feet.' Hinds, or female deer, are known for their agility and ability to navigate treacherous terrain with surefootedness. This imagery suggests that God equips believers with the necessary skills and fortitude to overcome obstacles and challenges in their lives. It speaks of divine empowerment for navigating difficult circumstances with grace and stability. Third, the phrase 'he will make me to walk upon mine high places' is a metaphorical expression of spiritual victory and dominion. Walking on high places symbolizes transcending earthly limitations, achieving a position of security and perspective, and experiencing a deeper connection with God. It implies that God elevates believers above their struggles, granting them a vantage point from which they can see His purposes unfolding. This is not about worldly success but about spiritual triumph over adversity. Finally, the inclusion of 'To the chief singer on my stringed instruments' indicates that this declaration of faith is meant to be expressed through worship and praise. It suggests that music and art are powerful tools for proclaiming God's faithfulness and inspiring hope in times of difficulty. The verse underscores Godâ€™s provision of strength, agility, and elevation for those who trust in Him, culminating in a call to celebratory worship.
application: In modern life, Habakkuk 3:19 offers profound encouragement and practical guidance for navigating challenges and maintaining faith. When facing personal struggles, professional setbacks, or global uncertainties, remember that 'The LORD God is my strength.' This isn't merely a positive affirmation; it's an active reliance on God's power to sustain and equip you. Seek Him in prayer, meditation, and Scripture, allowing His presence to fill you with courage and resilience. Cultivate habits that foster spiritual strength, such as regular fellowship with other believers and acts of service to others. Recognizing that God makes your 'feet like hinds' feet' means actively developing the skills and character traits needed to overcome obstacles. Identify your weaknesses and seek God's guidance in strengthening them. Learn from your mistakes, adapt to changing circumstances, and persevere in the face of adversity. Just as a hind navigates difficult terrain with agility, so too can you navigate life's challenges with God's help. Embrace opportunities for growth and transformation, knowing that God will equip you for every task. The promise of walking 'upon mine high places' encourages you to maintain a perspective of faith, even when circumstances seem bleak. Refuse to be consumed by negativity or despair. Instead, focus on God's promises and trust that He is working all things together for good. Seek opportunities to serve others, knowing that acts of kindness and compassion can elevate your spirit and bring you closer to God. Finally, express your gratitude and faith through worship and praise. Whether through singing, playing music, writing, or creating art, use your talents to honor God and inspire others. Share your stories of God's faithfulness, encouraging those who are struggling to hold onto hope. Let the message of Habakkuk 3:19 be a constant reminder that God is your strength, your provider, and your ultimate source of victory.
prayer: Heavenly Father, in the midst of life's storms, I come to you seeking your strength. You are my refuge, my rock, and my source of all power. Lord, I confess that I often feel weak and overwhelmed by the challenges I face. But I cling to your promise that you will equip me with the agility and surefootedness of a hind. Grant me the wisdom and courage to navigate the difficult terrains of my life. Help me to see beyond my present circumstances and to trust in your sovereign plan. Elevate me to your high places, where I can gain a clearer perspective and experience your peace that surpasses all understanding. I offer you my worship and praise, acknowledging your faithfulness and goodness. Fill my heart with gratitude for your unwavering love. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: This is a metaphor for God giving you agility, surefootedness, and the ability to navigate difficult and treacherous terrain with grace and confidence. It's about divine empowerment to overcome challenges.
